To Sask., July, 1923.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A note of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on Pioneer Life because no individual who has lived in the west will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. It is desirable to give details, or describe particular events, if you have had occasion to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual will be asked to answer. It has already been experienced by many others, so there is no need to worry about answering blank spaces or answering questions in a particular manner. If you have any answers to these questions, please fill them in.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether they were born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

To Sask. - July, 1952.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Mrs. Laura May Winn (Mrs. Henry)
2. Your address: 18th Ave., Saskatoon, Box 34.
3. Date: March 18, 1952.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   - Ontario, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   - William Winn
6. Did your parents own land at the time of your birth?
   - No
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   - Ontario, Canada
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may say "I was a small child")
   - I was about 12 years old.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - Apparently the program was, come west, grow up with the west. Bring the growing boy west, you can purchase a homestead for only $10.00 to own.
   - The wheat growing country.
   - Some of brother, sisters, and brother came down to see relatives, advised mother to bring family to the West.
LaRose, Laura May Winn (Mrs. Henry)

To Saskatchewan - July, 1932

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Laura May Winn LaRose
2. Your address: 116 Main St., Box 34
3. Date: March 18, 1932
4. Where were you born? (If you were born in Canada)
5. What was your father's occupation?
6. What was your mother's occupation?
7. How many children did you have?
8. How many of your children are still living?

We lived in Ontario, until moving to Saskatchewan in July, 1903.

Apparently the program was, come west, grow up with the west. Bring the growing boys west. You can purchase a homestead for only $10.00 down and dairy required. Come west get rich.

Some of Father's Siblings or Brother came down to the West.
It was rather interesting watching the passing trains or country pass by. Going around the great lakes when you could see both the snow and rain at the same time. We stopped over in Wpg for a few days. Then resumed our journey. It seemed all at once we arrived in Whitewood. Then was driven out to an uncle's farm.

We then settled up land in the Green Mountain section.

In 1912.

My brother was working for wages. Brother Harry the younger children in school doing what he could come to hand to support the family.
13. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to go to Western Canada?

Pathway relatives helped to get us finally settled.

14. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

Brother & I came to go there.

15. What means of transportation did you use?

We came by train.

16. What landmarks of the journey best do you remember? (Provide you will on the way, etc.)

It was rather interesting watching the passing farms or countryside pass by. Going around the great lakes when you could see both the fingers and rear of grain at the same time. We stopped over in Wpg for a few days. Then resumed our journey. It seemed odd at that time to see buildings, farm houses attached to the land. One just realized they were living among the large fields to the north as we went through.

17. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We arrived in Whitewood, then were driven out to an uncle's farm.

18. Where did you settle or take up land?

We took up land in the Qu'Appelle-Grasshopper section.

19. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Pathway Homestead, our own farm, where we settled in 1912.

20. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How often did you earn?

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1920? What reasons did they have for moving?

I don't think so.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Yes, several. I moved away during the 1920s but returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here giving dates whenever possible.

I held office in the Section of the Home Builders

In 1920, I also was Teacher of the Infant Class in Sunday School for about six years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were affiliated to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (See below) districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and location of patron suggesting place name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of the adoption. Any changes in name since then state the first name was given, date and reason for change.

Our district is called the Buffalo Plain School District.

It's name, originally, was the Buffalo that used to roam the prairies, when we first came here to Homestead.

The land was brought out from Town to a Community Center.

John Winn was discarded as your law became available.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, several. I moved away during the 1920s out west.

In 1918, I also was Teacher of The Infant Class in Sunday School, for about six years.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The change from oxen or horses drawn implements to tractor drawn machinery. combines.

The better house up to date way of farming.

Our elders were the real pioneers, we having a share in the pioneering too. Most of the first pioneers started passed on. Soon the second generation will follow suit.

40. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

The change from oxen or horse drawn implements to tractor drawn machinery embodies the slower pace of life of farming. Our elders were the real pioneers, not having a share in the pioneering era. Most of the first pioneers' land passed on. Soon the second generation will follow suit.
